The Company is involved in certain claims, suits and legal proceedings in the normal course of business . The Company has accrued for litigation and claims when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount of loss can be reasonably estimated . The ultimate outcome of these proceedings and actions is unlikely to have a material adverse effect on the Company's consolidated financial statements .
 The Company counterclaimed against GRIDCO for damages . In June 2007, a 2-to-1 majority of the arbitral tribunal rendered its award rejecting GRIDco's claims and holding that none of the respondents, the Company, AES ODPL, or Jyoti Structures, had any liability to GRIDCo . A hearing on the liability award has not taken place to date . The Company believes that it has meritorious defenses to the claims asserted against it .
 A prior operator of the pole factory, Companhia Estadual de Energia (CEEE) had been using those contaminants to treat the poles that were manufactured at the factory . In March 2008, the State Attorney of the state of Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, Brazil filed a public civil action against AES Sul, AES Florestal and CEEE .
 AES Redondo Beach, LLC, LLC filed a lawsuit against the California Coastal Commission (the “CCC”) over the CCC’s determination that the site included approximately 5.93 acres of CCC-jurisdictional wetlands . Potential outcomes could include an order requiring a restoration and/or pay fines or penalties . AES believes that it has meritorious arguments concerning the underlying CCC determination .
 In October 2015, AES Indiana received an NOV alleging violations of the Clean Air Act (“CAA”), the Indiana State Implementation Plan and the Title V operating permit related to alleged particulate and opacity violations at Petersburg Station Unit 3 . In February 2016, the EPA alleged violations of New Source Review and other CAA regulations . The settlement agreement, in the form of a proposed judicial consent decree, was approved by the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana on March 23, 2021 .
 In December 2018, a lawsuit was filed in Dominican Republic civil court against the Company, AES Puerto Rico, and three other AES affiliates . The lawsuit generally alleges that the CCRs caused personal injuries and deaths and demands $476 million in alleged damages . The relevant AES companies believe that they have meritorious defenses to the claims asserted against them and will defend themselves vigorously in this proceeding .
 The lawsuit generally alleges that the CCRs caused personal injuries and deaths and demands over $900 million in alleged damages . In August 2020, at the request of the relevant AES companies, the case was transferred to a different civil court . In May 2024, the Civil Court of La Vega dismissed the entire case due to the expiry of the statute of limitations . The claimants appealed the dismissal to the relevant intermediate appellate court .
 An ex officio action was brought by the SMA due to alleged exceedances of generation limits, which would require the Company to reduce emissions in order to achieve the emissions offset established in the Compliance Program . The cost of the proposed Compliance Program is approximately $10.8 million and is in the execution stage . The Company believes that it has meritorious defenses and will continue to assert them vigorously .
 CFE. ought to recover approximately $200 million in payments made to AES Mérida under the Contract, plus approximately $480 million in alleged damages for having to acquire power from alternative sources in the Yucatan Peninsula . The arbitration Tribunal issued its decision in the case in November 2022, rejecting CFE’s claims for damages .
 In February 2022, a lawsuit was filed in Dominican Republic civil court against the Company . The lawsuit purports to be brought on behalf of over 425 Dominican claimants, living and deceased, and appears to seek relief relating to CCRs that were delivered to the Dominican Republic in 2003 and 2004 . The Company believes that it has meritorious defenses to the claims asserted against it and will defend itself vigorously in these proceedings .
 Alleged charges include untimely completion of intake works and insufficient capture by the provisional works, irrigation water outlet and canal contemplated by an agreement with local communities . The claimants' attempt to recuse the presiding judge has been rejected by the relevant Dominican appellate court . The Chilean competition agency (the Fiscalía Nacional Económica or “FNE) opened an investigation regarding AES Andes’s declarations with respect to coal prices and coal blends used to generate electricity in Chile .
 The investigation is at a very early stage; AES Andes is currently responding to the FNE’s information requests . The FNE will independently conduct the investigation and will ultimately decide whether to dismiss the matter or initiate a judicial proceeding on the allegations in the confidential complaint . These types of investigations in Chile commonly last for years .
 As of December 31, 2024, $264 million remained available for repurchase under the Stock Repurchase Program . No repurchases were made by The AES Corporation of its common stock in 2024, 2023, and 2022 . There can be no assurance the AES Board will declare a dividend in the future or, if declared, the amount of any dividend .
 The AES Corporation has selected the Standard and Poor's 500 Utilities Index as our peer group index . The S&P 500 Utilities index is a published sector index comprising the 31 electric and gas utilities included in the S.P 500 . As of March 6, 2025, there were approximately 3,301 record holders of our common stock .

 The Company changed the definition of Adjusted EPS to remove the adjustment for  tax benefit or expense related to the enactment effects of 2017 U.S. tax law reform and related regulations . There were no such impacts in 2022 or 2023 . EBITDA is adjusted for the impact of NCI and interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, and accretion of AROs .
 Adjusted EBITDA with Tax Attributes adds back the pre-tax effect of Production Tax Credits, Investment Tax Credits (“PTCs”), and depreciation tax deductions allocated to tax equity investors, as well as the tax benefit recorded from tax credits retained or transferred to third parties . The GAAP measure most comparable is Net Income, which is based on net sales and net earnings .
 Given its large number of businesses and overall complexity, the Company concluded that Adjusted EBITDA is a more transparent measure than                 Net income-related . The allocation of earnings and losses to tax equity investors from both consolidated entities and equity affiliates is removed from Adjusted EBITDA . NCI also excludes amounts allocated to  tax equity investor investors from consolidated entities .
 The tax attributes are related to the Renewables and Utilities SBUs . It also includes the tax benefit recorded from tax credits retained or transferred to third parties . The AES Corporation's Adjusted PTC reflects the impact of NCI and excludes the items specified in the definition above . The company also includes net equity in earnings of affiliates adjusted for the same gains or losses excluded from consolidated entities .
 GAAP measure most comparable to Adjusted PTC is income from continuing operations attributable to The AES Corporation, which is determined in accordance with GAAP . The company believes that Adjusted PTC better reflects the underlying business performance of the Company and is the most relevant measure considered in the Company's internal evaluation of the financial performance of its segments .
 Adjusted EPS is diluted earnings per share from continuing operations excluding gains or losses of both consolidated entities and entities accounted for under the equity method . GAAP measure most comparable to adjusted EPS is dollaboration from continuing operations . We believe that Adjusted EPS better reflects the underlying business performance of the Company and is considered in the Company's evaluation of financial performance .
 Adjusted EPS should not be construed as an alternative to diluted earnings per share from continuing operations, which is determined in accordance with GAAP . Losses due to impairments, and strategic decisions to dispose of or acquire business interests or retire debt,  affect results in a given period or periods, which affect results .
